tickets.summary: Do not syntax color heredoc strings
tickets.description:
When writing code with a heredoc \(see example below\)
the string inside the heredoc should not be colored:

print &lt;&lt;LA;
This is my example heredoc. Here, the word 'my' would
be colored and the word use would be colored as well
because the syntax coloring interprets them as
functions and not as part of a string.
LA

posts.author: maiku41
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=766962

Unless the colorer is doing full parsing, it's hard to
determine if the code-looking strings in a heredoc are code
or not, as variable substitution is allowed in heredocs:

my $obj = Obj-&gt;new;

print &lt;&lt;EOF
The result of calling \$obj-&gt;method is: @\{\[$obj-&gt;method\]\}.
EOF

In this case, the first $obj-&gt;method should not be
highlighted, but the second should.  In general, parsing
double-quoted strings in Perl without using Perl itself is
NonTrivial\(tm\).
posts.subject: #8 Do not syntax color heredoc strings

posts.author: maiku41
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=766962

Just a quick clarification on my previous comment...  

The problem is not recognising varables embeded in strings,
but that the @\{\[ \]\} construct allow arbitrary code where a
variable substitution is allowed.  In the example,
@\{\[$obj-&gt;method\]\} calls $obj-&gt;method and places its value in
the string.
posts.subject: #8 Do not syntax color heredoc strings

posts.author: zachlipton
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=63694

Maybe we could just treat everything inside a heredoc as a 
string and color it that way. IIRC, that's what bbedit does \(I'm 
at school and not in front of a mac right now\) in its perl 
syntax coloring and I don't really mind it.
posts.subject: #8 Do not syntax color heredoc strings

posts.author: luelljoc

tickets.summary: annoying dos prompt runs every few seconds
tickets.description:
Hi there,

I'm using the plug-in on Eclipse 2.1 on Windows 2000 
pro.

While coding in the Perl perspective, a dos prompt runs 
every few seconds \(I guess for the perl interpreter\). The 
annoying thing is that it grabs the focus and one has to 
click \(or alt-tab\) into the eclipse editor window to get 
focus back in the editor.

Is there any way of stopping this? Its almost impossible 
to work with this.

Other than this, and a small oversight with the syntax 
highlighter, its a great plug-in. 

Many thanks indeed

Anthony Pereira

posts.text:

tickets.description:
One can customise the syntax highlighting to an 
amazing degree. However there is one faux pas that I 
have come across.

I like to have my background colour as black, and set 
the other syntax to have appropriate colours henceforth. 
However, the $ symbol is not part of any of the 
customisable group, and so remains black - always\! So 
one can't have a black background.

Any chance of fixing this?

Many thanks indeed

AP

tickets.description:
If the perl compiler segfaults during syntax checking,
the system becomes useless.  It appears to be
constantly writing to disk.  It seems to be in system
mode rather than user mode \(swapping?\) because nothing
else can get much CPU time \(thus can't kill Eclipse\).

A simple way to get perl to segfault -- at least on
this machine -- is to feed it the simple typo

tied STDIN

\(should have been 'tied \*STDIN'\).

Perhaps EPIC could trap the SEGV signal and prevent this?

tickets.description:
Your packages are named org.epic.\* which is wrong,
unless you own the epic.org domain.  You should rename
the packages to something less misleading such as
net.sourceforge.e-p-i-c.\*

posts.author: maiku41
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=766962

epic.org is currently registered to the Electronic Privacy
Information Center \(see www.epic.org\).

Note however that the package naming convention is exactly
that - a convention.  The ownership of domain names can and
does change over time. There is no guarantee that a
"correctly named" package will remain so over the course of
time.  I highly doubt in this era of corporate takeovers
that many companies will allocate tight IT $$ to rename
packages to match the new owner's primary domain name, even
if the old domain name is allowed to lapse.

It certainly is nice if the package name indicates where to
find the maintainer, and it might be a bit rude to drop in
on someone elses namespace - especially if they're active in
open source development - but there's no law preventing it,
and to claim it's "wrong" is a bit strong.
posts.subject: #33 Package names are incorrect

posts.author: pwillo
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=37866

If it looks like a domain name, people will assume it's a
domain name.  If you had named your packages epic.\* it would
have been obvious to all that you had chosen to simply
ignore the convention. However, org.epic.\* says to any java
programmer "This was produced by the people who own \(or at
least owned\) epic.org".  If you're going to have a randomly
named package hierarchy, don't use a tld name as the first
component.

It may be merely a convention, but so are a lot of things,
for instance:
checking your code builds before you release it
use strict;
\#\! /usr/bin/perl -w

Oh, and polluting another person/organisation's namespace
without there permission \_is\_ wrong, whether there's a law
or not.
posts.subject: #33 Package names are incorrect

posts.author: leo_forge
posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-rejected
posts.subject: #33 Package names are incorrect

Yes or No I just get a line followed by &quot;ERROR&quot; in my editor.
I am using:
Eclipse 2.1.1 on MacOSX 10.2.6 
Build id: 200306271545
Java 1.4.1

I think the reason is because there is no

\#\!/usr/bin/perl 

in the beginning of the file.

posts.author: luelljoc
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=274815

In the file eclipse/plugins/org.epic.ext.cbg.editor\_0.2.8/modes/catalog 
change the line  
FILE\_NAME\_GLOB=&quot;\*.\{pl,pm,ipl,cgi,PL,PM,IPL,CGI\}&quot; 
to 
FILE\_NAME\_GLOB=&quot;\*&quot; 

Now you can associate any file extension to the Perl Editor by using Eclipse 
preferences. 
The next release will have this change included.

tickets.description:
The default for "validate source when idle for" is 400 
seconds \(sic\!\). The label is wrong and should be 
milliseconds.

Also, above and below the slide bar for the 
milliseconds, there are ugly thick black lines 
\(Windows XP\).

When I change the milliseconds and click "OK", an 
error message pops up three times, saying "Error 
notifying a preference change listener"

Okay, I am using the non-supported Eclipse 3.0M8, 
but at least the "seconds" label should be wrong in 
Eclipse 2.1.2, too.

tickets.description:
First, Many Thanks for EPIC\!

I noticed that the perl editor became extremely slow 
when I was editing a package \(SPAMPD\).  I believe that 
I traced it to a lack of a final POD documentation =cut 
at the end.  The POD documentation is pretty lengthy in 
the code.

I believe that the =cut at the end is optional, yes, or 
that it is common to leave it off if at the end of a 
module? \(see 
http://search.cpan.org/~nwclark/perl/pod/perlpod.pod\)


Before I found this I ended up replicating the problem on 
Fedora Core 1 \(w/ dual 2.4ghz processors\), WinXP Pro, 
and WinXP Home, with various versions of java and a 
few versions of perl on the WinXP machines.  Boy do I 
wish I had worked over the code first, but I assumed it 
was OK because I run it already.

source can be found at 
http://www.worlddesign.com/Content/rd/mta/spampd/sp
ampd

Sorry for wasting time if this is Not a Bug.  I am not a 
perl pro, which is why EPIC will be so useful to me.

posts.author: onkel_tom
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1100436

Hi,

I'm having this problem \(editor gets slow, saving of a file
lasts > 5s with 100% Java CPU usage all the time\) with a
self written module.

I do have this =cut add the end of my POD.

When I save my module file with my POD, it lasts >5s with
full CPU usage. When I save it WITHOUT the POD, saving lasts
~1s.

The module can be found at
http://www.schnuecker.de/perl/Weather/Com.pm

was occurred randomly and no fixed pattern for my Perl

posts.subject: #94 Eclipse crash ocasionally

posts.author: leo_forge
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=703323

Hm', if it's about the auto-completation then I would guess
we have a problem to show the Tooltip-content, i.e. what
variables are available. Generally it should work, but quite
interesting, that you experience some problems.

What I would suggest, is to open an Bug Ticket at Eclipse
and see what the response is. Namely almost every Error
shown in the above logs stems from some kind of internal

tickets.summary: Performance Problems in Editor on LARGE files
tickets.description:
On very large files, e.g. Tidy.pm \(890KB, 32000 lines\),
the performance of keystrokes is EXTREMLY poor.
Entering a single stroke, takes about a sec. on my
machine. When opening with the regular TextEditor in
Eclipse, no problem at all.

===> Possible improvements:

1\) Handlecursor positioning was already adapted \(DONE\)
2\) As in another Bug already pointed out, is the
gnu.regexp could be improved with the java.lang.regexp.
\(Don't know if this helps\)
3\) Folding and Outline runs twice the Regexp-Routine
for searching within the SUBs and Modules.
4\) The ParseTask in the TODO-Task would be better
performant with .indexof  \(most likely\).

NOTE: Even with closed Outline and TODOs the
performance does not change dramatically. I also tried
little bit with commenting out the Colouring, but this
helps very limited.

posts.author: cyberian
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=508701

I've analysed what happend and this is the result:

Every time, cursor position changed, PerlEditor will look
for regions to ignore \(literal strings and comments\). To do
this, PerlEditor calls calculateIgnoreTypeHash\(\). This
method should look up for single quotes in double quote
regions, but the method get called with LITERAL1 as region
type, so calculateIgnoreTypeHash\(\) will look for unquoted
double quotes inside a double quote region. The result is a
full file scan for each call, because a unquoted double
quote never exist in a double quote region.

Here my patch to solve the problem:

Index: PerlEditor.java
===================================================================
RCS file:
/cvsroot/e-p-i-c/org.epic.perleditor/src/org/epic/perleditor/editors/PerlEditor.java,v
retrieving revision 1.51
diff -u -r1.51 PerlEditor.java
\--- PerlEditor.java	17 Feb 2005 22:02:34 -0000	1.51
+++ PerlEditor.java	12 Mar 2005 08:22:59 -0000
@@ -1132,7 +1132,7 @@
\}

if \(singleQuoteHash == 0\) \{ 
\-        singleQuoteHash =
calculateIgnoreTypeHash\(myDocument,"\'", "LITERAL1",
doubleQuoteHash\);
\+        singleQuoteHash =
calculateIgnoreTypeHash\(myDocument,"\'", "LITERAL2",
doubleQuoteHash\);
\}

if \(singleQuoteHash == doubleQuoteHash &&
singleQuoteHash \!= 0\) \{

Please test it and feel free to commit if this works for you
too.

Regards, Kai
posts.subject: #138 Performance Problems in Editor on LARGE files

tickets.summary: Syntax Highlighting: Style literal2 exceeds /../s and /../m

posts.author: leo_forge
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=703323

s and m modifier are interpreted as regexpr s/././ or m/./
whereas above it s interpreted as s;.;.; \(which is allowed\).
To check prior to s if there is a / would be an idea except
it could be as well:

$\_="o1";
print 1/s/o/1/; \#which does not work, but is valid code\!

=> The only way to deal this issue better is to have the
modifiers as well listed, but seems quite complicated task. 

Q: What are ALLLLLL allowed modifiers?
posts.subject: #133 Syntax Highlighting: Style literal2 exceeds /../s and /../m

posts.author: leo_forge
posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> leo_forge

posts.author: brusberg
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=974624

I see, thats why it stopped oftenly after vtwo ;, but not
always.

Concerning / prior to s: not enough, I oftenly use
s/abc/def/gis; \(global, case-insensitive and as single line\)

ALLL modifiers: AFAIK
m/PATTERN/cgimosx
s/PATTERN/REPLACEMENT/egimosx
tr/SEARCHLIST/REPLACEMENTLIST/cds
y/SEARCHLIST/REPLACEMENTLIST/cds
posts.subject: #133 Syntax Highlighting: Style literal2 exceeds /../s and /../m

posts.author: leo_forge
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=703323

Hm', I see. So, there is requested a list of chars, given in
a string. If a char is found, it is treated as modifier and
therefore colored the same way.

But what about 'm/./giZs' , i.e. illegal modifier? It would
stop colouring before Z, right?

p.S.: Currently workaround would be to add the stop after a
\#, eg. \#;;
posts.subject: #133 Syntax Highlighting: Style literal2 exceeds /../s and /../m

posts.author: brusberg
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=974624

I think, this would be best. Maybe a little bit tedious,
because the list of allowed modifiers depends on the
matching operator.

Stopping before an illegal modifier would be fine, because
this is perl's view of the code. So syntax highlighting
helps detecting erroneous code.

BTW: The workaround works fine. Another possibility is to
use sx as modifier. In most\(\!\) cases the x modifier doesnt
change the RE's behaviour.

tickets.summary: Problem with Linux scripts with plugin over Windows
tickets.description:
If I try to edit scripts that I wrote in a Linux
machine in a Windows XP machine, code folding and
outline don't work. The problem is that the scripts
written in the Linux machine have the UNIX end-of-line:
LF. If I change them with the Windows end-of-line:
CR+LF, then it works without problems.

I am reporting this bug against the current CVS version.

The expression $foo->format\(\) \(an invocation of a method
named format on some object\) breaks syntax highlighting
in source code which follows it.

The reason is that a SPAN rule from
org.epic.ext.cbg.editor/modes/perl.xml is applied
incorrectly to the above expression:

<SPAN TYPE="LITERAL2" 
REQUIRE\_WHITESPACE\_BEFORE ="TRUE" 
REQUIRE\_WHITESPACE\_AFTER ="TRUE" >
<BEGIN>format</BEGIN>
<END>.</END>
</SPAN>

Specifically, the REQUIRE\_WHITESPACE\_BEFORE part
does not work as expected. The bug seems to be caused
by cbg.editor.rules.ColoringWhitespaceDetector
whose isWhitespace method returns true not just
for real whitespace, but also for various punctuation
characters \(including >\).

posts.author: leo_forge
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=703323

Here as well it's hard to distinguish when it's a reference
and when it's the built-in function of Perl. And the
Whitespace-function works as design, cause whitespace is
interpreted as Whitespace + \(1-letter\)-operators.

So, I say: It works as desgined. Same problem would appear
if you wish to write something like $foo->print

You can try in the xml-code to adapt it, but frankly say,
don't know what the benefit of this should be.
posts.subject: #158 $x->format() breaks syntax highlighting

posts.author: leo_forge
posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-wont-fix
posts.subject: #158 $x->format() breaks syntax highlighting

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

The benefit is quite simple: syntax highlighting would work in the case
I described, as opposed to: half of the file has wrong syntax highlighting
because of one invocation of a strangely named method inside it.

Also, note that "it works as designed" does not mean "as intended".
posts.subject: #158 $x->format() breaks syntax highlighting

posts.author: leo_forge
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=703323

"it works as designed" => EPIC
"as intended" => Perl

You could send us code-changes and we'll verfiy against
side-effects. Your suggested change has to many side-effects.

You can add something like

Mark\_following -gt; 

which works \(and will be submitted to CVS soon\).

tickets.summary: Auto-indent does not work with spaces instead of tabs
tickets.description:
Reporting against the current CVS version:

Pressing the Enter key after an opening bracket is supposed to move 
the caret to the next line and one indent step to the right. This does not 
work when the option "use spaces instead of tabs" is enabled: the caret 
just moves to the next line in the same column as the opening bracket.

I have already implemented a fix for this one and I am posting it as a 
reference for ChangeLog and to prevent duplicate reports.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

Fixed in CVS.
posts.subject: #192 Auto-indent does not work with spaces instead of tabs

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed
posts.subject: #192 Auto-indent does not work with spaces instead of tabs

tickets.summary: Menu actions not linked to the active editor
tickets.description:
Reporting against the current CVS version:

Actions defined by PerlActionContributor are not linked correctly to the 
active editor. For example, if you open two editors, the "Toggle 
Comment" and "Go To Matching Bracket" actions will be linked to the 
first opened editor, no matter which one is active.

I have already implemented a fix for this one and I am posting it as a 
reference for ChangeLog and to prevent duplicate reports.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed
posts.subject: #195 Menu actions not linked to the active editor

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

Fixed in CVS.
posts.subject: #195 Menu actions not linked to the active editor

posts.subject: #183 Eclipse crash - SWTError: No more handles

posts.author: majkel-k
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=156780

A colleague of mine had the same problem; the editor crashed
up to 3 or 4 times a day.

I solved the probleme for eclipse 3.2 by changing the class
PerlImages. The problem seems that for each entry in the
proposition list a new image will be allocated but not
released. Changing to a PerlImages class similar to the one
used by the java editor and modifying all other classes
using this class, the problem did not occure again.

Anybody interessted in incorporating the changes? I could
send a diff, it should be revised by someone knowing better
the perleditor than I do.
posts.subject: #183 Eclipse crash - SWTError: No more handles

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed
posts.subject: #183 Eclipse crash - SWTError: No more handles

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907
Originator: NO

Fixed in 0.4.27/0.5.28. I replaced PerlImages according to majkel-k's suggestion.

tickets.summary: right mouse button context menu doesn't work
tickets.description:
A strange effect happens after installing epic 0.3.11
on eclipse 3.1.
eclipse works fine for some hours. But than the right
mouse button context menu in navigator doesn't appear
anymore and on every right click in navigator eclipse
freeze for about on minute. I'm using eclipse gtk on linux.

Markus

posts.author: ibartel
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1310661

I've experienced the same problem.
Unfornatly its hard to reproduce since the problem occurs 
randomly after some time.
The bug is very annoying and can only be solved by restaring 
the whole system.

Ubuntu Linux 64 bit w/ Java 1.5.04 \(64 bit\)
Eclipse 3.1 GTK - EPIC 0.3.11

thanks in advancve,
Ingo
posts.subject: #185 right mouse button context menu doesn't work

posts.author: progman32
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1250728

Same thing happens to me. Eclipse works fine for a while,
but for me, the right-click menu doesn't work until I make
an entire new WORKSPACE, and even then it dies after a
while. Kind of annoying... oh well. Maybe it's the newer
Java, it seems to have problems with many things \(I can
count 3 programs off the top of my head that I can't run
with 1.5...\) Good luck\!
Fedora Core 3 64-bit, 2.6.11-1.27\_FC3, java 1.5.04.
posts.subject: #185 right mouse button context menu doesn't work

posts.author: mkalkbrenner
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=361942

I discovered a workaround:
If you're not using epic's own perl pespective but any other
like p.e. the java perspective and add all epic related
views to it, the error doesn't happen.
So it seems that the error itself is related to the epic
perspective.

Markus
posts.subject: #185 right mouse button context menu doesn't work

tickets.summary: Syntax Coloring and Outline Error w/ File Test

posts.author: jumpinjavaninja
posts.text: Test.pl
posts.subject: #191 Syntax Coloring and Outline Error w/ File Test

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

The problem was that the filetest operators were not described as such in the 
syntax coloring specification \(perl.xml\) and would therefore be confused with 
regexp operators. Notice that -s was causing problems while some other 
filetest operators were not.

I updated perl.xml to explicitly include all filetest operators. Now it works as 
expected... let's hope without side effects elsewhere.

Fixed in CVS.
posts.subject: #191 Syntax Coloring and Outline Error w/ File Test

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

Fixed as of 0.4.0.

tickets.summary: Text Highlighting does not consider escape character
tickets.description:
My complete script is marked "blue" after a statement 
such as: 
/^\s\*\"\(\w+\)\"=\"\(.\*\)\"/

If I add a single \(but wrong\) " behind it, it's ok.
Highlighting should not care about letters behind a 
backslash.

posts.author: nobody
posts.text:
Logged In: NO 

sorry, I forgot my mail address: 
martin\_dietrich@gillette.com

BTW: Thank you for opening Eclipse for the Perl Community :-
\)
posts.subject: #186 Text Highlighting does not consider escape character

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

Fixed in CVS.

This is a partial fix because distinguishing a regexp start 
slash from the division operator is difficult. I recommend 
using m// instead of //.

Strangely one very nice feature of Eclipse, the "show
quickdiff" does not work in EPIC-manged buffers. It
works fine in other buffers, but when I edit perl code,
it does not work if line numbers are shown too. Is
there some workaround to show both line numbers and the
quickdiff? I am using EPIC 0.3.12 under Eclipse 3.1.0
under Linux.

tickets.summary: Moving caret up and down doesn't work as expected around { }
tickets.description:
Reporting against the current CVS version:

Moving the caret up/down does not position it at the end of line as it 
should \(see the Java editor for reference\). For example, consider the 
following sequence of actions:

1\. Enter "if \($foo\)" on a line.
2\. Hit Enter, add an opening curly brace below "if".
3\. The caret should move to the next line and indent right once.
4\. Now hit arrow up twice and then arrow down twice. The caret should 
end up in the same position as after step 3. However, it ignores the 
indent and stays on the column after \{. The indent whitespace is not 
gone, however. If you hit End, the caret jumps to its expected position.

The cause of this behavior is tricky - it results from an invocation of 
resetStyle in PerlEditor to remove highlight from a matched bracket. This 
changes the value of an internal variable columnX in the StyledText 
widget.

Fixing this bug requires throwing away most \(perhaps all\) of the \(non-
standard\) bracket matching code in PerlEditor and implementing 
ICharacterPairMatcher instead, just like the Java editor does. An 
additional advantage is that the platform then takes care of the actual 
dirty work of bracket highlighting. I already have it figured out, but so far 
my version does not support the "Smart typing" feature.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

Fixed in CVS. Reimplemented "smart typing" in a similar way to Eclipse/JDT.

tickets.summary: Open SUB Declaration doesn't work as advertised
tickets.description:
Based on the current CVS code, I am basically reopening
http://sourceforge.net/tracker/?
group\_id=75859&atid=545274&func=detail&aid=1111560

Consider a test case with a single script and one Perl module 
declaring a single subroutine, which the script invokes. Selecting the 
invocation in the script and "Open SUB Declaration" from the context 
menu will highlight the "use ModuleName;" line in the script instead of 
the subroutine's declaration in the module \(which should open in a 
new editor, if necessary\).

This is a bug because the actual behaviour contradicts that defined in 
the user's guide: "If the located SUB is not in the current editor, the 
location is opened automatically and highlighted." This bug can be 
turned into a RFE by updating the documentation or \(preferably\) 
corrected by implementing the expected behaviour. I will investigate 
the latter option pretty soon.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

Progress update/note to self:
I have completely rewritten LeO's code for this one. My implementation 
currently works okay for my needs. However, the processing of 'require's 
found in the original is still missing, and my @INC path search algorithm is 
implemented in the wrong place, so I am withholding it from CVS.

While implementing this one, it became clear that a reliable implementation 
of this feature is next to impossible because of Perl's dynamic type system 
and the possibility of source code inclusion at run time \(via 'require'\). Still, 
the current heuristics work acceptably for non-fancy, procedural \(not OO\) 
code. To be fair, we should update the User's Guide with a remark about the 
inherent limitations.

Another problematic \(but less dramatic\) issue is opening an editor for a 
module file located outside of the Eclipse workspace \(when a subroutine's 
declaration is found in it\). Until someone comes up with a better 
implementation, a message dialog referencing such a file will have to suffice.
posts.subject: #205 Open SUB Declaration doesn't work as advertised

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

Fixed in CVS.

This is a partial fix because I skipped the 'require' bit 
\('use' statements are processed, however\). Moreover, it will 
never work 100% reliably because requires can be computed at 
runtime and are not amenable to static analysis.

tickets.summary: syntax validation / error marking is not greedy enough
tickets.description:
With the new epic version 0.3.12 some errors are not
reported anymore in the "problems" view and also not
marked in the "editor" view. 

Culprit for these missing errors is a too weak pattern
for parsing the  "perl -c" output.

With a test file like this:
\----
\#\!/usr/bin/perl

use strict;

\# no my - reported
$test;

\# bad syntax error - not reported
if \{\}
\----

perl -c would give the following output:
...
Global symbol "$test" requires explicit package name at
poe.pl line 6.
syntax error at poe.pl line 9, near "if \{"
poe.pl had compilation errors.
...

But in eclipse/epic only the first error is reported.

Looking at the class ParsedErrorLine shows that the
pattern 

private static final Pattern errorLineNoPattern =
Pattern.compile\("^\(.\*\) at \(\\\S+\) line
\(\\\d+\)\\\\.$"\);

is used for error report matching. This matches the
first report of the "perl -c" output, but not the
second report. 

So the pattern must be changed or a new case must be
added so that the second error report is also
matched/found and reported/marked.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

Well observed. I committed a partial fix for CVS: changed the regexp to

private static final Pattern errorLineNoPattern =
Pattern.compile\("^\(.\*\) at \(\\\S+\) line
\(\\\d+\)\[\\\\.,\]"\);

It is still not perfect because it discards the ", near "if \{"" part of the error 
message. Still better than ignoring the error altogether. Maybe you know if 
there is a specification of the Perl error messages' format anywhere? EPIC's 
current parser was written by trial and error.
posts.subject: #206 syntax validation / error marking is not greedy enough

posts.author: nobody
posts.text:
Logged In: NO 

Hello and thank you for the fast response\!

Regarding the question if there is a specification of the
error messages of perl:

I searched a bit, but found nothing really precise.

Only piece of information I gathered was by grepping through
the perl source code.

In file toke.c \(lexer for perl\) there is a function
Perl\_yyerror that generated messages that resembles error
messages as I know them.

But this is mainly guessing as I do not really understand
what the code is doing.
posts.subject: #206 syntax validation / error marking is not greedy enough

posts.subject: #204 Syntax highlighting broken after regexp

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

The fault lies in ExtendedPatternRule.endSequenceDetected, which takes 
the first \(escaped\) slash inside of the regular expression for its terminator. It 
does behave so because "ignoreEscape" is false \(indeed, it is never set to 
true anywhere in ExtendedPatternRule, so what's the point of this private 
variable?\).

I am committing a fix which sets ignoreEscape to true in the constructor for 
the affected rule \(as well as some others, as a side effect\), without claiming 
that I understand the scanner's convoluted code. Syntax highlighting still 
works ok after this fix, based on cursory checks of some large source files. 
Feel free to undo the fix if it causes worse, yet unnoticed problems.
posts.subject: #204 Syntax highlighting broken after regexp

could be changed color in the Editor->Syntax section?

tickets.description:
NullPointerExceptions may be encountered when the PerlEditor 
closes. The problem is that the helper threads are sent a dispose 
from PerlEditor.dispose, and at this time the SourceViewer widget has 
already been disposed by the platform. So the threads \(like outline 
page updater, folding...\) may still attempt to access a disposed 
SourceViewer and fail before they are stopped.

This can be best demonstrated by opening and quickly closing the 
editor on a large Perl source file. The folding thread does not even 
manage to do a single run before the editor is closed, resulting in a 
NPE.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

There are more problems of this sort, all caused by EPIC's blatant access to 
edited documents from multiple threads while ignoring the possibility that 
they may \(and indeed, will\) change while the user is typing. You don't need 
to close an editor to see the bugs, editing a larger file on a slower machine 
is enough.
posts.subject: #214 NPE when closing editor

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

The proper way to implement the outline page and folding functionality 
seems to be by implementing the IReconciler and IReconcilerStrategy APIs. 
Ideally, they should enable EPIC to incrementally update the secondary 
models based on changed regions of the document, instead of simply \(and 
slowly\) reprocessing the whole document after each change.
posts.subject: #214 NPE when closing editor

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

Fixed as of 0.4.0.
posts.subject: #214 NPE when closing editor

tickets.summary: Folding does not work reliably in 0.3.12
tickets.description:
Folding does not work quite reliably in any version, but the 0.3.12 
testing version is definitely broken due to my committed 
"improvements" of bracket matching.

Basically, the folding thread inappropriately uses the bracket matcher 
in such a way that only brackets visible on the screen are found 
\(therefore, invisible subroutines are not annotated with the fold icon\). 
Fortunately, the fix is easy and I shall commit it when I get through my 
current epic round of refactorings.

posts.author: leo_forge
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=703323

I don't wanna go into flame-war. It would be fine if your
improvements with the following fixes reestablish the same
functionallity as before.

Ie the code folding did inspect if the matching bracket is a
regular text or marked as something else \(e.g. reg-exp,
quote, etc.\). So, does the 'easy fix' includes that as well?
posts.subject: #216 Folding does not work reliably in 0.3.12

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

LeO, the fix I mentioned above does preserve the original 
functionality.

Note that there are big changes ahead, in particular to the 
syntax highlighting code \(I suppose originally authored by 
you\). See my message in the developers forum. Jochen and 
Stephan's stand \(expressed by email\) is for these changes to 
be committed to HEAD.

I agree, of course, that CVS commits should not generally 
break existing functionality. However, I see two major 
issues with following this rule under current conditions:

First, there is no automatic regression test suite that one 
could run before committing changes to obtain a "green 
light". This means that checking for regression bugs has to 
be done manually. Not only is this work-intensive, but 
sometimes plain impossible, if you delegate this task to new 
committers who don't know what to check. However, it seems 
to be the only way, considering that the original authors 
lack time for going over each commit themselves. \(Note the 
fact that I have discovered the folding problem myself.\)

Second, preserving existing functionality is easier when 
changes are small and incremental. However, no small and 
incremental change is going to solve the performance 
problems and syntax highlighting bugs present in the 
currently released version of EPIC. With big changes come 
big chances and big risks.

To address the first issue, I have started the pseudo-plugin 
org.epic.perleditor-test in the repository. It would be 
great if we could make it comprehensive enough to cover the 
existing functionality \(bracket matching is already 
included\!\)

My hope concerning the second issue is that we can constrain 
the ensuing problems to the CVS and possibly to the 
"testing" version of EPIC, to take advantage of public QA. I 
think it is better for new bugs to appear and become fixed 
quickly than for the old bugs to remain open for ages and 
become declared invalid instead of being fixed. If you think 
otherwise, maybe both worlds can co-exist, constricted by 
the "stable" and "testing" versions. That would be something 
new to talk about with the project admins.
posts.subject: #216 Folding does not work reliably in 0.3.12

tickets.summary: Syntax colouring wrong for ? within qq {} block
tickets.description:
If I have the following block

my $sql = qq \{
select \* from table where key = ?
\};

then the rest of the file treats the ? as the beginning
of a $test ? $true : $false block for the purposes of
colouration.

if I remove the space between the qq and the \{ then the
problem does not occur.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

The problem is that the 'qq' is not recognised as a quote 
operator if there is a whitespace following it instead of a 
delimiter character.

I'm afraid it will have to stay this way - no whitespace 
after quote operators in front of delimiters. If this bug 
was fixed, then typing "qq" in front of a space \(and, as a 
matter of fact, also typing "q", "m", "s" etc.\) would 
immediately cause the parser to interpret it as the start 
of a quote expression. This is undesired because it causes 
major delays when editing a large file: you start out 
typing "my $x" somewhere in the middle of the file, and 
after you press "m" the whole rest of the file is coloured 
differently because the parser thinks you are about to 
enter a m/atch/. I could make an exception for qq, qx, qw, 
and qr, but I am not sure if it is a good idea. It would 
make the parser's behaviour inconsistent.
posts.subject: #272 Syntax colouring wrong for ? within qq {} block

posts.author: nobody
posts.text:
Logged In: NO 

it fails also with this expression

my $back = \(
$ENV\{REQUEST\_URI\} =~ '/query/logoff.cgi'
? $self->query->param\('back'\) || $self->global->config->appDir
: uri\_escape\( $ENV\{REQUEST\_URI\} \)
\);

if I remove the ? everything is ok.
posts.subject: #272 Syntax colouring wrong for ? within qq {} block

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

This latest problem has easy workarounds. For example write m'/query/logoff.cgi' to convince EPIC that you 
are matching a regular expression or put parentheses around the left-hand-side expression of ?, as follows:

\($ENV\{REQUEST\_URI\} =~ '/query/logoff.cgi'\) ? ...

contents of which display: "The currently displayed page
contains invalid values."

Clicking OK allows you to change sections.

Now, changing to the Editor window:

All form values are blank. 

Even the "Appearance color options" does not contain the
categories I would expect. Seems to me that the preferences
or config settings are missing from the distribution.

This is in a fresh eclipse 3.2.0 installation with EPIC
3.0.12 installed via updates from
http://e-p-i-c.sourceforge.net/testing immediately after
installing eclipse.

tickets.description:
Maybe I'm just too lame to find it, but there doesn't
seem to be any way to get EPIC understand that a file
that don't end it some specific extension is a Perl
file. It doesn't grok \#\!/usr/bin/perl, there's no way
to set any kind of "This file is Perl" property, and I
can't even select Perl by right clicking on the file.
Even setting \*.\* = Perl in Eclipse File Associations
doesn't make it match extensionless files \(and it
rejects plain \*\).

I think it's a pretty serious limitation. I think it
should at least let select Perl from the right click
menu, it the architectural limitations make it
difficult to get it detect \#\! or set the properties.

tickets.description:
Following the instructions, I have Eclipse 3.2 and 
Perl 5.6.1 installed.  

From the running Eclipse window:
I go to Help->Software Updates->Find and Install, 
where I click 'Search for new features to install'.

->Next brings up the 'Update sites to visit" window, 
and I click 'New Remote Site'.  I give it a 
name 'EPIC' and a URL 
'http://e-p-i-c.sourceforge.net/updates/'

Now I click the 'OK' button, going back to the 
'Update sites to visit" window, where the 'Next' 
button is greyed out.  I click 'Finish', and it seems 
to be trying, but ends up with the 'Problem Occurred' 
window, where the 'Details' button shows a message 
saying "Unable to access http://e-p-i-
c.sourceforge.net/updates/".

I noted along the way that the parent directory shows 
that all of the EPIC update subdirectories were 
modified on 09/25/06, two days ago, and in 
the 'Plugins' subdirectory, all of the files have 
the '?' icon at the left.

posts.author: jshields
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=19910

Just another comment on this one. It seems that once the
TreeViewer becomes null for a particular editor source file
then it never comes back until you close it and re-open the
file. My \(rather uninformed\) guess is that there is a "root
problem" lurking somewhere that is causing the TreeViewer to
become null in the first place.

This all seems to happen for me when I invoke the source
formatter. \(I'm a habitual formatter, I run Ctrl-Shift-F
after almost every Ctrl-S.\) This may not be accurate, but I
feel like I can almost make it happen by doing the following
in quick succession: edit a file, Ctrl-S, Ctrl-Shift-F. I'm
also running on Linux over remote X windows. I'm not sure if
that setup can allow user events to come in when they are
usually blocked by the UI thread \(or something\)??

I hope that is helpful\!

Thanks for the great work on this project\! \(I hope to be
able to find some time to supply tests and/or patches...\)
posts.subject: #311 The outline view is not updated when the source is formatted

tickets.description:
I spent 1.5 hours trying to install EPIC. I tried several times, and everytime, when Eclipse restarted it exited with a fatal error message. This essentially made it impossible for me to use Eclispe at all.

Eventually, I was able to install it by answering no to the last question which was asking me if I wanted Eclipse to be restarted. Instead, I answered no, and exited Eclipse manually, then restarted manually.

This time it worked.

This is a major issue. Installing a plugin should never cripple the whole IDE.

tickets.description:
Most source files do not include a copyright or license in them. The project itself doesn't declare or distribute a license for the source or binary versions. 

By not having copyright's and license's the project source code and binary's are not  legally distributable. In most jurisdictions copyright law states the authors reserve all rights unless explicitly given. Therefor source files and your binary distributions that don't contain a copyright statement or license are not allowed to be copied or distributed.

In short - no license's means your project is not open-source and worse anyone downloading your work is breaking copyright law.

Please select a appropriate open-source software license, include it in each source file and make it easy for people to know what license you've selected by including that information in your FAQ.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907
Originator: NO

Aren't you exagerrating a bit? You can see and accept the CPL license during installation through the update site \(as described in the manual\) and you can also see it after installation by going to the Help menu and showing feature details. The license is also named in the project description here on SourceForge.

Anyway, since you did not manage to find it out, I conclude that it should indeed be made more apparent in the web site.

tickets.description: Eclipse has a "Mark Occurrence" feature \(toolbar button looks like a yellow highlighter\). In EPIC, this works correctly when the cursor is placed in the middle of a variable name in the source code editor -- other uses of the same variable are automatically highlighted in the source. But when the cursor is placed in the middle of a comment, other comments are automatically highlighted\! This is nonsensical\! This feature should be disabled when the cursor is placed inside a comment.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907
Originator: NO

I agree with you.
posts.subject: #370 disable "mark occurrence" for comments

posts.author: jacktanner
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=661682
Originator: YES

This feature should also be disabled at other times:
\- when the cursor is placed next to a string delimiter \(including single quote, double quote, and qw\)
\- when the cursor is placed inside a string
posts.subject: #370 disable "mark occurrence" for comments

posts.subject: #363 debugger running continuously without stopping

posts.author: cfrito
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1845660
Originator: NO

Could we please raise the priority of this bug?  It happens when single-stepping in almost any Perl code, so, effectively, the debugger is broken.  It will single-step several lines OK and then more or less stall.  The debugger says it is running \(in the stack\), but the user can't single-step any more nor continue.  Most of the debug menu options are grayed out.
posts.subject: #363 debugger running continuously without stopping

posts.author: cfrito
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1845660
Originator: NO

I upgraded to EPIC 0.6.11 after having disabled 0.5.38 and found that the reported problem did not happen any more \(at least so for in my testing\).  I did see another debugger problem that probably is unrelated but is worth mentioning -- the debugger failed to open and display the file into which it stepped after pressing F5, although pressing F5, F6, or F7 apparently worked normally otherwise, as one could see from the stack.

This bug went away when I removed the following statement from my main program, Aggregator.t:
use lib 'lib', '../lib';
and instead added 'lib' to the Perl include path in the project properties.

My directory structure was the following:
event\_processor
lib
EP
Aggregator.pm \(package EP::Aggregator\)
t
Aggregator.t \(the main program or test module for EP::Aggregator\)

Most likely, the debugger is not paying attention to 'use lib'.  I think all 'use lib' does is unshift the list of directory names onto @INC.

Perhaps someone could add this to the bug list as a separate bug -- I'm running out of time this evening.

print "abc".chr\(0\)."def\n"; \# only "abc" printed in Eclipse

tickets.description:
My EPIC version is 0.5.39.

When I try to debug a Perl script \(content doesn't matter\), I get the following error in the console:

Can't use an undefined value as a symbol reference at /usr/lib/perl5/5.8.8/perl5db.pl line 5375.
\(in cleanup\) Can't use an undefined value as a symbol reference at /usr/lib/perl5/5.8.8/perl5db.pl line 5375.
Compilation failed in require.
at /tmp/test.pl line 0
main::BEGIN\(\) called at /usr/lib/perl5/5.8.8/perl5db.pl line 0
eval \{...\} called at /usr/lib/perl5/5.8.8/perl5db.pl line 0
BEGIN failed--compilation aborted.
at /usr/local/share/imperia/trunk/cgi-bin/pws.pl line 0
Debugged program terminated.  Use q to quit or R to restart,
use o inhibit\_exit to avoid stopping after program termination,
h q, h R or h o to get additional info.  
DB<1> 

After a while an alert pops up "Timed out while waiting for Perl debugger connection".

I think the problem is related to this one: http://rt.perl.org/rt3/Public/Bug/Display.html?id=41461

The corresponding section in perl5db.pl is:

sub print\_lineinfo \{
\# Make the terminal sensible if we're not the primary debugger.
resetterm\(1\) if $LINEINFO eq $OUT and $term\_pid \!= $$;
local $\ = '';
local $, = '';
print $LINEINFO @\_;
\} \#\# end sub print\_lineinfo

$LINEINFO is supposed to be a file handle but it is undefined and this causes the error.  When I comment out the print statement, the debugger in Eclipse still doesn't work.  I no longer see the error message but I still get the timeout.

I can reproduce that behavior on the command line:

PERLDB\_OPTS="noTTY frame=2" perl -d printenv.pl

This produces exactly the same error message \("Can't use an undefined value as a symbol reference ..."\).  What is the culprit here? Perl or EPIC?

Thanks,
Guido Flohr
guido@imperia.net

posts.subject: #584 An internal error occurred during: "PerlDebugJob". Java heap

posts.author: *anonymous
posts.text:
Hold up I changed the INI file section

FROM: 
\--launcher.XXMaxPermSize
256m
-vmargs
-Xms40m
-Xmx256m

TO:

\--launcher.XXMaxPermSize
256m
-vmargs
-Xms512m
-Xmx1024m
-XX:+UseParallelGC
-XX:PermSize=256M
-XX:MaxPermSize=512M

and this resolved the issue.  Thanks

tickets.description:
perl syntax checking is making my system crawl when I open a large perl project.\(20,000 source files\)

Can you please make it so perl syntax checking is not automatic, it is only done on request?

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: You can untick "Project > Build automatically". Is that not sufficient?
posts.subject: #641 perl syntax checking performance

posts.author: faldore
posts.text: how can I syntax check just one file?  \(and the things it depends on recursively\)
posts.subject: #641 perl syntax checking performance

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: You can check just one file by saving it. This triggers a syntax check. You cannot check dependencies automatically because EPIC doesn't do any dependency tracking.
posts.subject: #641 perl syntax checking performance

posts.author: samson_
posts.text:
I think unsetting "Build automatically" is not really an option.

At work we also have ~10.000 file projects. I found that once you went through the initial "pain" of validating your project, EPIC reacts quite snappy. Still, if you have to change branches frequently, this still causes a lot of files to be rebuilt.

One possible improvement would be not spawning one perlcritic process per file, but try to batch multiple files into one perlcritic run. Maybe there are other areas where we could avoid spawning perl processes...
posts.subject: #641 perl syntax checking performance

tickets.summary: Cannot run/debug perl script with no extension
tickets.description:
It is common practice for commonly used 'tool' scripts to be created WITHOUT an extension.

For instance 'tool' rather than 'tool.pl' or 'tool.perl'.

However, the run/debug setup in EPIC doesn't allow a file with no extension to be specified.  If you do, the "Run"/"Debug" button is ghosted, and you are unable to execute the script.

This is, imho, a serious limitation.

tickets.summary: New install with old workspace adds <> to perspective name
tickets.description:
\(submitting on behalf of Jim Cooper\)

Repeatable steps:

1\.       Install Eclipse to a clean subdirectory, and open a new workspace.
2\.       Install latest E.P.I.C.
3\.       Open Perl perspective, and make sure it is active.
4\.       Close Eclipse, delete the subdirectory, but save the workspace.
5\.       Re-install Eclipse, and open the saved workspace.
6\.       Notice the perspective name has a set of <> added around the name.
7\.       Repeat starting at Step \#2.

Every time through this cycle, another set of <> are added around the name.  My current Eclipse says I have the <<<<<<<Perl>>>>>>> perspective open - see attachment.

tickets.summary: A not set ENV causes red error icon.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-invalid
posts.subject: #622 A not set ENV causes red error icon.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: You will get the same errors if you attempt to compile your code on the command line with perl -c a.pl. Not an EPIC bug.
posts.subject: #622 A not set ENV causes red error icon.

posts.author: larum2
posts.text:
Ok, thanks. 2 questions:

\- Do I have another option than export the environment vars before starting eclipse? I deactivated the validation every n seconds in the Epic menue, but that did not help. An I tried to set tne ENV in the run configurations, but that did not help, too.

\- Where can I read about this behaviour and EPIC? I serched much withoud having any idea or hint. The tooltip of the red icon says nothing really helpfull.
posts.subject: #622 A not set ENV causes red error icon.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
In order to check the syntax, EPIC invokes perl -c on each file, which indeed inherits the environment from Eclipse. The compilation stage in Perl does actually execute code \(from BEGIN blocks, but also variable initializers in modules, as in your case\). The errors you see are emitted by your own code being executed, hence not related to EPIC.

Making sure the environment of Eclipse is set up as necessary is one option. Another one is to modify your code so that it doesn't execute and attempt to access the environment until you actually run the script \(which is a good practice, generally speaking; the whole concept of automatically running code while it is being compiled appears crazy, but hey, we're talking about Perl\).
posts.subject: #622 A not set ENV causes red error icon.

posts.author: larum2
posts.text:
Ok, thanks. 

Is it possible to add documentation to sub x in a.pm. Than use the sub in another .pl and get it's documentation here as tooltip or something?
posts.subject: #622 A not set ENV causes red error icon.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: No, it's not possible \(not currently implemented in any form and also impossible to implement well for Perl in general\).
posts.subject: #622 A not set ENV causes red error icon.

posts.author: larum2
posts.text: That's a pity, but thanks again. So I need not to search anymore. Nevertheless I think I will change from Emacs to EPIC. The last think I'am looking for is autocompletion for subs. INDIV->test\_sub\(\);  does work very well, but it is not recommended to call a sub as method. Calling it  INDIV::test\_sub\(\) is not recommended, too. Does EPIC support autocompletion for subs? So that I can write te, press STRG+Space and it works? Maybe after a little configuration? \(-:
posts.subject: #622 A not set ENV causes red error icon.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: EPIC doesn't attempt to find out which symbols are or aren't imported when you use a module \(which would require running parts of your code\). So the autocompletion only works after :: or -> \(the latter rather badly for variables, using a regex to find a constructor call and infer the type of the referenced object\).
posts.subject: #622 A not set ENV causes red error icon.

tickets.description:
When I use Eclipse feature to Open Declaration of a function, it finds the epic\_links version of the file, instead of my actual file.

I do not notice till I make a change and try to test it and see that it looks like I made no change at all, to discover I have made all my changes to epic\_links files instead of real files.... \*headdesk\*

is there some way to disable the epic\_links?  I dont want eclipse to find those files when I try to Open Declaration.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
"Open Declaration" uses the include path to search for files. By tweaking your Perl Include Path \(in project properties\) you should probably manage to get it arranged so that it hits your wanted files before the unwanted ones.

You can try deleting epic\_links, but in itself it won't help - this is just a pseudoproject that is recreated each time when EPIC needs to access some file located outside of Eclipse's workspace. The key to solution is to make it harder for it to even consider accessing such files, which, as described above, is governed by the @INC path.
posts.subject: #650 Open Declaration opens epic links

posts.author: faldore
posts.text:
I think that EPIC should set up the @INC automatically such that the epic\_links are the last thing that is searched by Open Declaration.

Furthermore, I think that the epic\_links should be read only and not accept changes from the user.  \(The UI should prevent changes\)
posts.subject: #650 Open Declaration opens epic links

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
The search for modules is done doing the project's effective @INC path, which consists of whatever you specified in the Project Properties dialog first and anything that the system include path contains later. So epic\_links is already the last thing, unless you \(unnecessarily\) put the system include paths into your project properties.

As for readonly, it is up to the filesystem to determine which files are and aren't  readonly. As a matter of fact, the capability to edit modules from epic\_links aids debugging \(if you know what you're doing - temporarily editing system files\). If you want them readonly, just make them readonly at filesystem level for whichever user runs Eclipse.
posts.subject: #650 Open Declaration opens epic links

posts.author: samson_
posts.text:
- **status**: open --> closed-invalid
- **Group**:  --> v0.6.x
posts.subject: #650 Open Declaration opens epic links

posts.author: samson_
posts.text: Works as intended.
posts.subject: #650 Open Declaration opens epic links

tickets.description: Compile errors produced when files 'use' each other and use MooseX classes and has statements.

posts.author: *anonymous
posts.text: WM_Utilities
posts.subject: #572 Compile errors when using MooseX

posts.author: *anonymous
posts.text: Generic_Pattern_Matching
posts.subject: #572 Compile errors when using MooseX

posts.author: *anonymous
posts.text:
When viewed in Eclipse/EPIC the attached files report a comiple error, and yet the code runs OK.  The problem occurs only with the recursive 'uses' statements and the 'has' statement.
EPIC debug 0.6.27
EPIC Editor 0.6.24
EPIC source pluin 0.6.35
posts.subject: #572 Compile errors when using MooseX

posts.author: nigdig
posts.text: As our project grows, this is getting to be a significant annoyance, in that many of the files are marked as errored.  All of the perl code does however run with no errors.  I have rechecked with EPIC 0.6.36 in windows, and with the latest Perl 5.10.1 \(with and without the cwd.pm file fix\) and  all packages at the current release as of 26/6/2010.
posts.subject: #572 Compile errors when using MooseX

posts.author: nigdig
posts.text: Workaround found.  Strictly this is probably a Perl::MooseX issue in that the error also occurs if the pm file is built outside of Eclipse, which is why Eclipse flags it up as an error.   The fix is to insert a 'use Moose;' line immediately before the has statement in those modules where the error occurs.
posts.subject: #572 Compile errors when using MooseX

tickets.summary: Source Formatter should honor .perltidyrc in project root directory
tickets.description:
By default, perltidy command will follow below precedences while formatting code:
1. command line options
2. .perltidyrc in current directory
3. .perltidyrc in user's home directory

But, from EPIC, perltidy command is executed from EPIC's script directory, which causes perltidy to not honor .perltidyrc from project root.

If SourceFormatter or ScriptRunner can fire the command from projects root directory, perltidy will honor project specific settings for perltidy.

NB: On testing branch, we pass below command line options, from IDE preferences:
perltidy -q --indent-columns=4 --maximum-line-length=120 --entab-leading-whitespace=4

posts.author: samson_
posts.text:
@jploski what about reading/writing the perltidy settings into a project root .perltidyrc? This would avoid contradicting settings between perltidy on command-line and perltidy called from epic. perltidyrc is also respected from other tools, like this perlcritic rule: 
http://search.cpan.org/dist/Perl-Critic-1.123/lib/Perl/Critic/Policy/CodeLayout/RequireTidyCode.pm
posts.subject: #667 Source Formatter should honor .perltidyrc in project root directory

posts.author: sf8435934
posts.text:
Today I started getting this same error when opening an Embperl file in EPIC, a file that has been working EPIC for years. Thinking it was a problem with my code, I removed all of the code and started pasting it back in bit by bit. What I found though had nothing to do with my code, but seeming with the number of lines or characters or something. I reached a point where I could open the file fine. However, if I then added an extra blank in a particular region of code, then I could no longer open it in EPIC; it would give me the same "Failed to create the part's controls" the OP reported. Remove the blank line (which doesn't change the meaning of the code any, just makes it easier to read) and the file opens up fine without any errors.

I went so far as to download the latest Eclipse, resetup EPIC, create a fresh workspace, and have the same issue. Any ideas what's happening? I've tried both EPIC 6.56 and 6.57 and both have the same issue.

tickets.summary: Refactoring before a warning marker can cause broken internal state
tickets.description:
I'm using EPIC as part of an RCP app where the application allows to inject text snippets into the editor. This is done through the standard Eclipse Refactoring API using the PerformRefactoringOperation class and a refactoring that creates a number of TextFileChange objects for the actual insertions. After the injection the new code is formatted using EPIC's SourceFormatter class and the original text is replaced with that formatted version. Last the application enforces a saving of the editor by setting the corresponding TextBuffer object to be dirty and saving it.

When having a perl script that is longer than the editor size and having a warning marker in the first function defined in that script then injecting such text seems to cause some kind of internal state corruption. This is visible by eventually having a white number ruler as well as never reaching line '1' in the number ruler when scrolling down and up again. Instead the number ruler will show a seemingly random number larger than one at the top line (see the attached screenshot).

Along with that visual glitch there are errors logged by Eclipse in the workspace log coming from some sanity checks in the various Editor-related classes:
~~~~

posts.author: mazenkilani
posts.text:
I have exactly the same problem. Installed Eclipse but cannot install EPIC by any published URLs or packages. At the age of 'it just works', this is frustrating. Grateful for a quick response or fix the website links if needed. The text refers to much older versions of Eclipse anyway and simply does not work:
"For the impatient: Select Help > Software Updates... in Eclipse, add the update site http://e-p-i-c.sf.net/updates/testing"
posts.subject: #679 unable to install EPIC editor  for Eclipse

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
I just checked, and it works for me.

I suggest unchecking the "Contact all update sites during install to find required software" checkbox in the dialog where you select the EPIC version to install. Based on experience, this option tends to causes problems and long delays during installation of software.
posts.subject: #679 unable to install EPIC editor  for Eclipse

posts.author: aerogoneer
posts.text:
Hello,
I tried to intall epic again w/ the unchecked  "Contact all update sites during install to find required software" but still not successful. it is still unable to connect to repository...attached is the screenshot. Appreciate any help on my issue.
posts.subject: #679 unable to install EPIC editor  for Eclipse

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
The file content.xml referenced in your error message does not exist on the server. However, in my tests it is not even requested. I'm using the following version, downloaded straight from eclipse.org, not installed via some package manager or some such (it may matter):

Eclipse IDE for Java Developers
Version: Luna Service Release 1a (4.4.1)
Build id: 20150109-0600
(Linux, 32-bit)

My Java version is
java version "1.6.0_34"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.6.0_34-b04)
Java HotSpot(TM) Server VM (build 20.9-b04, mixed mode)

In any case, you should be using the Java VM from Oracle, not OpenJDK. See also this thread: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19290108/eclipse-kepler-doesnt-allow-me-to-install-plugins

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: Not really related to EPIC or Eclipse, but some types of connectivity problems in Java can be alleviated by setting the system property  java.net.preferIPv4Stack to true. (You can pass it to the Eclipse executable like so: "eclipse -vmargs -Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true").

tickets.summary: Timed out while waiting for Perl debugger connection
tickets.description:
Running EPIC produces "Timed out while waiting for Perl debugger connection" error along with "Unable to connect to remote host: 192.168.1.37:5000
Compilation failed in require...."

OS X 10.11.1 (El Capitan, darwin 15.0), Eclipse Kepler 4.3.2, EPIC 0.7.0 (same thing happens with 6.5.6),
Perl 5.18 (prebuilt for darwin) or ActiveState Perl 5.20

Any suggestions?

posts.author: mimohodom
posts.text: It looks like I found the answer. The IP address mentioned in the error message is the one that I had statically added in the hosts file. For some reasons EPIC searches this address for debugger connection skipping dynamic addressing assigned by DHCP.
posts.subject: #687 Timed out while waiting for Perl debugger connection

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed

MORE FOLLOWUP: \(solved and a hint too all people like me\)

As this is clearly related to ERR output from perltidy. I
read the manual and add the '-q' switch to perltidy. Now it
works for me. 

And I suggest the EPIC should include -q as the default
switch for perltidy. \(perldity also recommend this if it is
used in any editor\).

tickets.summary: Minor parser bugs regarding compound expr. and here-docs
tickets.description:
A bug in the parser somehow causes parentheses to be
identified incorrectly if a division expression has
been broken across multiple lines and the division mark
has been \(admittedly inadherent to good coding
guidelines, but we all make mistakes :\)\) positioned at
the beginning of the next line:

print\("The result of the calculation \(", $divider
/ $divisor, "\) is invalid.\n"\);

Another minor bug in the parser causes the following
sub, while being syntactically correct, to appear as an
unterminated sub \(i.e. sub that extends past the end of
the file\):

sub example\(\) \{
print\(<<EOF\);
Lalala.
EOF
\}

The print statement is parsed correctly and the sub
block is properly recognized if parentheses around the
here-doc marker are omitted.

posts.author: gregab
posts.text: - **summary**: Minor parser bugs regarding prototypes and here-docs --> Minor parser bugs regarding compound expr. and here-docs

tickets.summary: Perl Auto Builder extremely slow, Cancel does not work
tickets.description:
I am reporting this one against version 0.3.8 \(testing\).

I have a  project which consists of 271 small CGI Perl scripts 
\(average size 4 KB\) and 27 modules \(average size 20 KB\). 
Invoking "Project/Clean..." causes the Perl Auto Builder to kick in, 
which takes forever to finish \(several minutes\) with a high CPU 
load, shows no progress in the Progress view \(Building 
workspace status stays at 6%\) and does not allow itself to be 
cancelled.

Improving performance would be most welcome, showing 
progress and allowing cancellation of Perl Auto Builder next best.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

The slowness is apparently caused by creating a new "perl -c" process 
for each of the validated scripts. Each such invocation takes less than a 
second, but it sums up. I am not sure if there is a way to batch validation 
without executing perl anew each time. A trivial test shows that it would 
help enormously: validating a single 1,5 MB file is an order of 
magnitude faster than validating hundreds of several KB big files. I 
suspect that perl does some lengthy initialization on startup which could 
be somehow avoided.
posts.subject: #122 Perl Auto Builder extremely slow, Cancel does not work

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

I did some profiling and indeed more than 90% of the time is spent in "perl -
c" outside of EPIC code. So far I could not confirm the theory that the 
startup/initialization time dominates each "perl -c" invocation, though.

In the meanwhile I implemented build cancellation and build progress 
reporting and will upload these improvements to CVS when/if I get a chance.
posts.subject: #122 Perl Auto Builder extremely slow, Cancel does not work

posts.author: jploski
posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed
posts.subject: #122 Perl Auto Builder extremely slow, Cancel does not work

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

As of 0.4.0, both showing progress and cancellation are 
implemented.

tickets.summary: Environment variables missing when running scripts
tickets.description:
I have several scripts which make use of XML::LibXML. 
This module relies on the location of libxml2.dll being
present somewhere in the PATH environment variable.

Everything worked well in EPIC 0.3.8 and then I
upgraded to 0.3.9 hoping some unrelated issues were
fixed.   Now when I attempt to launch any of the
scripts I receive the following Windows dialog box:

"perl.exe - Unable to Locate Component

This application has failed to start because
libxml2.dll was not found. Re-installing the
application may fix this problem."

Needless to say, I uninstalled and reinstalled all
related libraries to no avail.

The next thought I had was that the PATH variable was
not being properly set any more.  To test this, I
created a batch file and entered its location into
"Window -> Preferences -> Perl EPIC -> Perl executable".

Batch file contents:

\---

@echo off

echo ----- >> c:\perl\bin\perl\_debug.txt
echo Start >> c:\perl\bin\perl\_debug.txt
echo ----- >> c:\perl\bin\perl\_debug.txt
echo Current directory = %CD% >> c:\perl\bin\perl\_debug.txt
echo Command line = %CMDCMDLINE% >>
c:\perl\bin\perl\_debug.txt
echo Environment: >> c:\perl\bin\perl\_debug.txt
set >> c:\perl\bin\perl\_debug.txt
echo. >> c:\perl\bin\perl\_debug.txt

\---

After running a script with the new perl "executable"
and checking the resulting text file, I noticed there
were two scripts being run.

The first was "c:/Program
Files/Eclipse/plugins/org.epic.debug\_0.3.0/get\_env.pl"
and didn't even exist at that location.  The
environment variables were defined correctly for this
script.  However, the enviroment variables for the
second entry \(the originally launched script\) were
devoid of everything but the COMSPEC, PATHEXT, and
PROMPT environment variables.

Working around the issue can be achieved by replacing
the batch file contents with the following:

\---

@echo off
set PATH=%PATH%;C:\Perl\bin
perl %1 %2 %3 %4 %5 %6 %7 %8 %9

\---

I would gladly roll back to EPIC 0.3.8 if older test
versions were available through either the update site
or the project files page.  As it stands, only the most
recent version is on the update site.

posts.author: luelljoc
posts.text: - **priority**: 5 --> 7
posts.subject: #124 Environment variables missing when running scripts

posts.author: matisse
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=586139

What is happening here is that EPIC is compiling the file,
and thus executing the BEGIN block - maybe we need an option
to \*not\* compile files until the user has at least once said
"I've looked at this code and it is OK to compile"? Maybe
only files that have a BEGIN block?
posts.subject: #247 Background Perl Processes very dangerous

posts.author: matisse
posts.text: - **priority**: 5 --> 8
posts.subject: #247 Background Perl Processes very dangerous

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

There are two options which govern whether and when a file 
is compiled:

"Project / Build automatically" is the general Eclipse 
option which causes modified resources \(saved files\) to be 
rebuild.

EPIC's own preference "Validate source when idle for X 
seconds" controls how often an edited file is checked in 
background without being saved.

That said, I am not sure that these options work correctly 
now, that is, it could be that files are compiled on save no 
matter what - which would qualify as a bug.
posts.subject: #247 Background Perl Processes very dangerous

tickets.description:
I am running Eclipse v3.1 on openSuSE v10.  I installed
the latest version of the EPIC plugin.  I used CPAN and
the shell to add the PDL module to Perl, add the
directory to @INC, and verify that the information in
@INC was updated.  When I create a script with "use
PDL;" Eclipse/EPIC generates the following error:
"Can't locate PDL.pm in @INC."  It also shows the
contents of @INC.  The problem is that the contents of
@INC displayed by Eclipse/EPIC do not match the
contents listed when using  the shell.  BTW, I have
also tried to push the path of the new directory onto
@INC from inside Eclipse/EPIC, and I have tried the
"use lib path" approach.  Under no circumstances does
Eclipse/EPIC find the PDL.pm file even though it is
there.  Any ideas?

Duane Armstrong
curtis.d.armstrong@nasa.gov

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

You should try setting the @INC path in project properties.

There are problems with paths containing backslashes in the @INC under Windows. As a workaround, you should use slashes instead of backslashes in Windows paths.

posts.author: bayblade
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=969951
Originator: NO

I've come across a similar problem:
If I call 

use FindBin;
\# possibly more complicated search paths than this get created based on 13 years of gruesome logic
use lib "$FindBin::Bin/.."; 

Epic completely disregards the use lib statement.

setting @INC path in project properties cuts it to a point, but
ordering or simply availability of include paths results in different behaviours at runtime for different machines and environments--it would be nice having the editor run the same way as the script itself, and not have to configure and juggle the paths for 50 copies of Eclipse \(juggling the environments is hard enough\)
posts.subject: #254 @INC update problem

posts.author: jploski
posts.subject: #254 @INC update problem

posts.author: szepi
posts.text:
Hi,

I had the same problem on Mac OSX.
However, I figured that my command line interpreter was 
/opt/local/bin/perl,
while in the IDE, the interpreter used was 
/usr/bin/perl.
In the EPIC preferences of the IDE I changed the perl interpreter to be used from 'perl' to '/opt/local/bin/perl', and I also moved away /usr/bin/perl and created a symbolic link to /opt/local/bin/perl \(my preferred perl installation\). 
This solved the problem and my script happily runs.
Maybe one of these steps alone would also be sufficient, but I did not test this.

Hope this helps.
\- Csaba
posts.subject: #254 @INC update problem

tickets.summary: Perl Runner does not expand variables
tickets.description:
Hi, 

an Eclipse launch configuration provides the feature of
variable expansion. After defining a variable in a
launch configuration with "Variables..." in section
Arguments->Program Arguments \(or Arguments->Perl
Arguments\) the variable typically is automatically
expanded when the launch is started. E.g., the variable
$\{project\_path\} is expanded with the current path to
the project. Or $\{folder\_prompt\} prompts with a dialog
for the folder. However, the perl launcher does not
expand these variables \(the java launcher does\). It
would be nice to integrate this feature in the perl
launcher, too \(or deactivate the button "Variables..."
\(my versionb is EPIC 0.4.13, Eclipse 3.2.1\).

Best regards,

Ulli

tickets.summary: Cannot execute scripts from linked folders
tickets.description:
Reporting against 0.3.12 and the current CVS version:

If you create a Perl project with a subfolder linked to 
a folder outside of the workspace, you will not be able 
to run scripts contained in the referenced folder \(even 
though you can create run configurations for them\). It 
seems that the script path resolution algorithm does 
not take linked folders into account.

Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

Fixed in CVS.

tickets.description:
As of 0.4.2, elements of the include path configured in 
project properties which refer to non-existing 
directories are dropped by EPIC. This behaviour is not 
very intuitive and causes trouble in the Cygwin 
environment. There, the entered include paths have to 
be Cygwin-compliant, thus not being valid native 
Windows paths. A workaround with setting Perl 
interpreter type to 'Cygwin' is not applicable if the 
paths must refer to symlinked directories.

See https://sourceforge.net/forum/message.php?
msg\_id=3860247 for discussion of this problem.

tickets.summary: EPIC removes all problem markers for Perl files
tickets.description:
The PerlValidator class periodically \(or at least at
startup\) removes all problem markers from all Perl files. 

If another plugin adds a problem marker to a perl file
for its own purposes it will also be removed. That's
not nice.

Instead, EPIC should define its own marker type that
extends the problem marker type and operate only on it:

Sample plugin.xml code:

<extension id="epicMarker"
name="Perl Problems"
point="org.eclipse.core.resources.markers">
<super
type="org.eclipse.core.resources.textmarker"/>
<super
type="org.eclipse.core.resources.problemmarker"/>
<persistent value="true"/>
</extension>

In addition all references to IMarker.PROBLEM in
PerlValidator should be changed to the new marker id.

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907

Can you submit a patch?
posts.subject: #306 EPIC removes all problem markers for Perl files

The 

Java Persistence API Tools \(1.0.0.v200706250000-77--CYQCCz-CoRPCCCH\)
requires feature "org.eclipse.datatools.enablement.feature"

is an issue with the "Eclipse IDE for Java EE Developers" EPP package. The error occurs while installing any additional feature; see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show\_bug.cgi?id=194959

This specific package is currently no longer available for download at http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/

Workarounds:

-1- wait for a new version of this EPP package ;-\)

or

-2- choose the "Eclipse IDE for Java Developers" as described by Jack Tanner, using the 0.6 update site http://e-p-i-c.sf.net/updates/testing \(at this very moment the EPIC updates sites are down\)

or

-3- follow the instructions at http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylyn\_FAQ\#Installation\_Troubleshooting

tickets.description:
When restarting eclipse all leading and trailing
whitespaces are removed from all templates.
For example, the template

"
=head1 NAME

B<$\{filename\}$\{cursor\}> - 

=cut
"

is trimmed to

"=head1 NAME

B<$\{filename\}$\{cursor\}> - 

=cut"

which is no valid POD :\(

A possible workaround for trailing spaces is to include
an additional $\{cursor\} variable which will be ignored.
When no cursor is needed this is indeed possible for
leading whitespaces too, but it is very annoying to
move the cursor manually.

EPIC version is 0.4.21, behavior on versions prior to
this is unknown.

posts.author: schirrmeister
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1645053

Well it is valid POD if there is a blank line before it, but
one may need to add an empty line at least before the =head1.
posts.subject: #336 whitespaces trimmed on templates

tickets.summary: Invalid source recoding during syntax check
tickets.description:
I have many perl files with characters in cp1251 \(windows-1251\) encoding.

In properties of my project and all my directories I've specified "cp1251" as a default encoding.
Source files are opened correctly in editor - there is no problem with visual editing.

But there is a big problem with syntax check:
all cyrillic characters are converted to "?" signs and this causes errors while syntax checks.
For example if there is a sequences of cyrillic letters in regular expressions, those sequences are converted to "?????", so an error "Nested quantifiers an regex" appeared.

Can I solve this problem by changing project/workspace setings, or there is a promlem in EPIC that should be fixed?

posts.author: jploski
posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=86907
Originator: NO

Which platofrm are you on - Windows or Linux?
posts.subject: #343 Invalid source recoding during syntax check

\#
\# Java VM: Java HotSpot\(TM\) 64-Bit Server VM \(1.5.0\_19-b02 mixed mode\)
